Answer: No.Because there is no such thing as ‚Äúwhat everyday life should actually be like‚Äù.
name: Claire Jordan
question: https://www.quora.com/As-technological-advances-ever-continue-to-evolve-turning-us-into-a-24-7-world-are-we-losing-sight-of-what-everyday-life-should-actually-be-like

Answer: That has been known for a long time, long enough to be a given. Now people are having a hard time believing a syndrome in our children that causes serious psychological problems is caused by deprivation from nature. Many parents do not believe there is an actual problem caregorized as a mental problem that is easily cured by taking your children for walks out in natural, beautiful areas away from the mad confusion of uncivilization. Indeed, many psychologists don't believe it. Perhaps those who do not believe that being sequestered from a natural environment causes mental problems are victimsThat has been known for a long time, long enough to be a given. Now people are having a hard time believing a syndrome in our children that causes serious psychological problems is caused by deprivation from nature. Many parents do not believe there is an actual problem caregorized as a mental problem that is easily cured by taking your children for walks out in natural, beautiful areas away from the mad confusion of uncivilization. Indeed, many psychologists don't believe it. Perhaps those who do not believe that being sequestered from a natural environment causes mental problems are victims themselves.Personally, I have seen the problems of our society from a very early age, so although I have always believed in good hard work and the good things in life, I have never actually been a part of the world nor a sucker for what it offers. This being so, I have always been conscious of the importance of goals, and have balked at doing anything to support this evil system of things. I have always objected to paying taxes because so much of them pay for killing people, for example. I have not heartily pursued putting my inventions on the market because I did not want to give more life to a doomed, failing world. Can you imagine having a vehicle that did not run on petroleum products? The world would be a whole different place had I shown it how to build different kinds of engines, engines way more efficient and pollution free.But: ‚ÄúAs technological advances ever continue to evolve?‚Äù What a phrase! Technology is merely knowledge applied to effect a specific function or purpose, often utilized by a mechanical contrivance. The word is based in ancient Greek, and there meant art, or artificial.Mankind observes things in his environment, and from this learns the knowledge and principles by which it had been built, and then applies that knowledge to build something for his own purposes. This making of something artificial based on the knowledge learned from the natural environment is called technology. The contrivance made can be good or evil according to the purpose of the one making it. Weapons are made for evil purposes, but they are an example of technology.People nowadays seem to worship technology as though it were an entity with a life of its own doing miraculous things. This should be no surprise, because they worship evolution in the same manner. Science, too. Science means knowledge, though, but science does not create knowledge, it discovers the knowledge already created. But tell me, please, since evolution is supposed to be a turn to something better, an advance, how you can evolve an advancement? Isn't that superfluous?Technology comes from the minds of men applying the principles nature teaches, and thus there is nothing new under the sun. Technology does not advance. Men find new things to do with the existent knowledge of nature, that is all. So, the evolution of the advancement of technology, as you call it, is merely men building new contrivances to fulfill their own goals.‚ÄúHaving sustenance and covering, we shall be content with these things.‚Äù Really, is not life about working to produce food to eat, houses to live in, clothes to wear, and loving and communicating with fellow man, and taking care of this beautiful planet in all of itsThe nature of our environment and our own nature are integrated, but nature does not depend on us, we depend on nature. Therefore, everything which takes us away from nature is detrimental to our own nature, to our existence.The world has been 24/7 since it began. People have lost sight of what we naturally are, how we should be living for a long, long time. Technology is not bad, but people come up with contrivances for harmful purposes, and such contrivances are bad. Contrivances for harmonizing us with nature are good.Go natural, worship God.Peace and love.
name: Dima Vorobiev
question: https://www.quora.com/As-technological-advances-ever-continue-to-evolve-turning-us-into-a-24-7-world-are-we-losing-sight-of-what-everyday-life-should-actually-be-like

Answer: Trouble is - what SHOULD everyday life actually be about?Should we all strip naked and go live in caves - from which we hunt large game animals with stone tools and forage for berries?Who is the arbiter of what ‚Äúlife should be like‚Äù?The fact is that life has been changing for the entire existence of humanity - and who is to draw a line at some point on the calendar and say ‚ÄúTHIS IS NORMAL!‚ÄùFact is, humans have evolved these big brains in order that we can be supremely flexible - that we can develop new ideas and new ways to continue the species despite difficulties.So I don‚Äôt know what you thiTrouble is - what SHOULD everyday life actually be about?Should we all strip naked and go live in caves - from which we hunt large game animals with stone tools and forage for berries?Who is the arbiter of what ‚Äúlife should be like‚Äù?The fact is that life has been changing for the entire existence of humanity - and who is to draw a line at some point on the calendar and say ‚ÄúTHIS IS NORMAL!‚ÄùFact is, humans have evolved these big brains in order that we can be supremely flexible - that we can develop new ideas and new ways to continue the species despite difficulties.So I don‚Äôt know what you think we‚Äôre losing sight of.Maybe we‚Äôre just GAINING sight into what we should ultimately become?In my opinion, once mankind took the step of replacing evolutionary development with the thousand-times-faster pace of technological development - we broke with anything that we could remotely describe as ‚Äúnormal‚Äù.When my son was younger - and social media and cellphones started to take off - I‚Äôd worry that he was heading into a dangerous path. We talked about it a lot - and his perspective is an interesting one.He grew up in a world where everyone you know is in instant communication with everyone else - where information is no longer hard to obtain. This is a RADICALLY different place than the world the I grew up in where information was essential and a valuable resource - and communications were relatively slow paced.I have no grounds to say that his generation are wrong and mine were right.Truly - there is no objective way to say ‚ÄúThis was good - and that is bad‚Äù.So - with the current pace of change, we‚Äôve hit a novel point in human development where the rate of change is so steep that each generation lives in an entirely different world than the previous one.Perhaps this is good - perhaps it isn‚Äôt - but unless someone can come up with solid reasons why we were the last generation to ‚Äúget it‚Äù - then we should shut up and see where it leads us.
name: Syed Asghar

Answer: I had been a devout Communist until I started working in propaganda in the early 1980s. When I was little, I couldn't quite understand why my parents never joined me in my imperialist fantasies about how the world would be wonderful, once Communism triumphs across the earth.In 1984, I first read the Gulag Archipelago, and was shattered. It was too overwhelming. Yet, it didn't mismatch most of what I already knew about the system, and what my dad and mum told about their lives. I had to absorb it somehow.Since I still wanted a career in propaganda, I never discussed what I read with anyone aparI had been a devout Communist until I started working in propaganda in the early 1980s. When I was little, I couldn't quite understand why my parents never joined me in my imperialist fantasies about how the world would be wonderful, once Communism triumphs across the earth.In 1984, I first read the Gulag Archipelago, and was shattered. It was too overwhelming. Yet, it didn't mismatch most of what I already knew about the system, and what my dad and mum told about their lives. I had to absorb it somehow.Since I still wanted a career in propaganda, I never discussed what I read with anyone apart from my wife. Once you start working for Soviet rule, walls grow ears. Much of what you do and assume only you know about, in effect silently accrues into a solid volume of your personal file in some place you‚Äôll never find.I didn't want to risk it. I chose to think what happened in the era of Stalin was kind of an occasional apocalypse which the Communist idea somehow survived. Now, I thought, we were slowly recovering. All we needed was correct the wrongs. Which I considered my job: do it the right way.Then, Gorbachev came, with hisThen, Yeltsin took power, and his men kicked me out of the profession. My country died.Decommissioned from propaganda, I went into sales and never looked back. Ever since, I consider myself an ideological agnostic.Picture: a Soviet propagandist in ideological AWOL, anno 1991.

Answer: Q: What's an example of evolution in everyday life?A: Every cold you have ever had. Women select mates based on the traits they see as fittest, and men do likewise.And, over time, we become taller, brainier, and possessed of fewer teeth and ligaments. More and more humans are born without wisdom teeth ever appearing.And then there is just random evolution, of which we are unaware at the moment. Humans might be selecting for greater affluence, which in turn selects for greater skill at certain activities thatYes!How? The same way they‚Äôve always evolved. Some babies don‚Äôt live. Some adults don‚Äôt reproduce. Women select mates based on the traits they see as fittest, and men do likewise.And, over time, we become taller, brainier, and possessed of fewer teeth and ligaments. Our appendices are likely shrinking, and may someday vanish altogether. More and more humans are born without wisdom teeth ever appearing.And then there is just random evolution, of which we are unaware at the moment. Humans might be selecting for greater affluence, which in turn selects for greater skill at certain activities that were unknown (or worthless) in days past. So typing skills are probably being selected for, as an example.Who knows what form future humans might take?!

Answer: That's a question with hundreds of thousands of answers. I'll name just one. This:the spindle and distaff, was replaced by this:the spinning wheel, which in turn was replaced by modern spinning machines. Women used to spend huge amounts of time spinning thread and yarn. While people still knit and crochet, and a few still weave with hand looms, almost nobody spins fiber by hand any more. It's completely mind-numbing and there is no creativity or craft in it, unlike knitting.That's a question with hundreds of thousands of answers. I'll name just one. Answer: No. That‚Äôs not how evolution works. Evolution is about the adaptation of species to their ever-changing environment generation by generation. Its not about humans being ‚Äú allowed‚Äù anything - it is a natural process.Technology slows biological change since it improves adaptation. Consequently there is no reason to expect any drastic changes in human biology.

question: https://www.quora.com/As-technological-advances-ever-continue-to-evolve-turning-us-into-a-24-7-world-are-we-losing-sight-of-what-everyday-life-should-actually-be-like

Answer: Modern technology removes natural selective pressure. That‚Äôs largely the point of modern technology.But since natural selective pressure is essential for evolution (not just in Darwinism, but in every theory of evolution that anyone has ever come up with), removing natural selective pressure means eliminating evolution along with it.Our technology is designed around making it easier for us to live as the kind of beings we already are, adapting our environment to ourselves so that we don‚Äôt have to adapt to our environment.That removes the process of adapting to our environment, which renders evModern technology removes natural selective pressure. That‚Äôs largely the point of modern technology.But since natural selective pressure is essential for evolution (not just in Darwinism, but in every theory of evolution that anyone has ever come up with), removing natural selective pressure means eliminating evolution along with it.Our technology is designed around making it easier for us to live as the kind of beings we already are, adapting our environment to ourselves so that we don‚Äôt have to adapt to our environment.That removes the process of adapting to our environment, which renders evolution entirely pointless anyway. So there won‚ÄôtThere can be devolution, since that doesn‚Äôt require adaptation to the environment. But 2020 technology still requires somewhat naturally adapted humans to make, maintain, and successfully use it. So there‚Äôs a limit to how far humans could devolve before the technology would no longer remove their need to adapt to the environment.

Answer: Technology and evolution have nothing to do with each other. We would be the same as we are today. Evolutionary changes happen over very long periods of time and are part luck that the trait is consistently passed from generation to generation.Technology changes very quickly and keeps changing or disappearing, like the vacuum tube. It has nothing to do with the evolution of any living thing.
